newsitem.title: UK: INSIGHT - COPPER SEEN MOVING SIDEWAYS.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - COPPER SEEN MOVING SIDEWAYS.

text.p: 3 MONTH CLOSE * SUPPORT * RESIST * RSI14 * MA10 * MA30
Copper, stuck in a $2,250-$2,300 price range so far this week, is expected to continue drifting for now against a background of neutral technicals and the seasonal slowdown, analysts said.
Aluminium is more fragile in the near term, with prices seen taking a look at initial support at $1,680.
COPPER - Near-term technical indicators had started to flatten out from the recent downtrend and a positive close on Wendesday suggested a test of $2,300 resistance was possible.
Next resistance was seen around $2,335 and $2,370.
But the market was seasonally sluggish and might have trouble generating sustained buying interest, analyst added.

"With the slower summer period and stocks increasing, we expect copper to drift, whilst expecting to see signs of strength encounter increased selling pressure," said analyst Martin Squires of brokers Rudolf Wolff.
On the downside a breach in the band of support around $2,270-$2,260 could trigger sell stops and send prices reeling towards $2,225, analysts said.
Three months copper was quoted at $2,287/92 per tonne at 0800 GMT, versus $2,290 at Wednesday's kerb close.
ALUMINIUM - The market's recent downward correction was probably not over, chartists said.
The recent rises in LME stocks had contributed to the decline.

"On the charts, the moving averages appear to be topping out and with the RSI still declining there may be more scope to test the downside. Support is evident at $1,685 and $1,650," brokers Brandeis said in a commentary.
Three months aluminium was trading at $1,698 at 0800 GMT, compared with $1,696 at Wednesday's kerb close.
